So we were discussing those and the way it went that each of us got about only 10 projects, but we had to do the remote evaluation, which I found very good because you can really focus.
You can have books, you can have literature.

Go back to literature or review some recent literature to understand the project itself, so you are very well knowledgeable when you come to Brussels, and then each projects was evaluated by 5 different experts and then we met there all of us.

Here in some certain enzymes and proteins and then of course they ask you also if you have some broader knowledge in the field and you also list this other areas that you don't know very much about, but you know a little bit about them.
So you got about 25 projects.

So to evaluate at home, and this is again we met that embraces and we then discuss the project and rank them, and so this was really tough ranking because we had a route altogether 900 projects and about 100 evaluators focused gathered on these topics in one week and rank them all.
So again there was 15% of of successful.
Projects are together not very much so.
The competition is very strong here, especially in life Sciences.
And now I was instructed to give some my personal views on what qualities young or anyone.
Of course, not only agreement, should have to become in valuator.
What kind of personal qualities you have to have to come to Brussels and sit around the table that are experts gathered, you have to be very flexible in your mind.
Not only think in the frames of your discipline, you have to be.

Open to many other discipline and try to understand them all as much as you can, and you have to focus not in a discipline or area, but on the problem and how to solve it with all different types of knowledge is you have you have to be curious.
You have to be curious for what's new, what was discovered yesterday, what will be discovered tomorrow.
So really be at the edge of your scientific discipline and you have to have good communication skills.
And of course most of you here I think.
Have that and of course, Brussels or wherever the evaluation takes place is a good opportunity for networking, which is one of the great advantages of being an evaluator.
You meet people in many projects, at least for myself.
I know started from meeting people there and then inviting them or being invited and starting a new collaborations.
A new project that you write based on your new scientific connections.
And of course you have to be ambition.
Ambitious, which is a word that sounds perhaps bad.

You are ambitious for money for your good position or job, but in this case you have to be ambitious to learn more and more, and constant learning is something that you do or your life actually, and we are good listener as well.
Listen to others.
Be ready to compromise.
Be ready really to focus to be flexible and focused on the problems with all this.
Experience and skill.
Those that you have.
So is there a problem for a woman becoming evaluator and while becoming an scientist 1st and we all have some experience in this, we have problems in society edwr.
Rick, as well as at home and I'm also giving you some figures from our Slovenian recent data that we collected.

Namely, I am also, as I mentioned, at the beginning of my presentation, the Member and I actually established here in Slovenia, the National Committee for Equal Opportunities of Genders in Science and Higher Education.
Of course I get the motivation from purses specially from Bridget Regan as some of you know, and so we establish this committee here at our Ministry of Science and Education at that time.
So we are starting to collect some data, some statistical analysis, and as you can see here in Slovenia from 93 to 2000, 2001, we did not improve very much.
I mean, we improved in having more PhD students.
Nearly half of the page students, doctors of science are women, but when you come down, of course, you all know these scissors, diagrams and so on.
We all have full professors, percentage of full professors, which is close to 11.
And this dropped in last.
10 years of or so after our independence.
So it's a bad sign and I'm afraid that this new political situation.
This will even drop even more, so we have to be very active in this field too.

To really encourage the women not only the women, but also a society itself to accept women scientists we have made and also an interesting calculations of humans earning creative to men at the Public Research Institute by the academic grade in Slovenia in 2003.
And as you can see here, the total earning actually is a little less in general because we have of course legislation and law.
And before law in front of this law we are all equal.
We have equal points when we start the career or even when we are at a certain position.
But when it comes to other functional supplements or stimulations we can see that this dropped when women increased in the career.
So the working environment is not very friendly to us.
They tried to discourage us in terms of giving us this privileges, and this is kind of subtle discrimination that we are all or some of your experience.
Is also at home.
But we are not giving up.
We do.
We did improve in certain fields in certain parameters in certain in certain.
I would say achievements, Rich or certain, goes.
There are more women beneficiaries from research funds in Slovenia.
Compared to 10 years ago, there are more women being members of the Council of Science and Technology.
For example, member of National Certificate Council, member of Scientifical for Technology Development and so on.
So we are progressing slowly.
In this so here are just some goals of our national committee that I listed.
I'm not going through all of that with you, but major thing what we did in improve what we did achieve in improving social environment is that we were we did influence some legal regulations.
We have participated in three important acts that were launched in 2002 and three.
And we try to monitor all relevant subsystems as I just have showed you before, we are trying to create a better work environment for women.
For example, we really want to have the same valuation of achievements of women and men which are not always the same, although on the paper yes, but in practice no.
And we want to, for example, disseminate and create new female role models and so on and so on.
Also we want to.
Improve to really work with women personally individually, to encourage them to get more self confidence to get more self esteem.
And certainly we do not accept any aggressive male behavior at work and in the center.
Community instead, what we cherish is the coexistence, compassion.

All these female values as they say, but they have to be have to not subordinate male, but they have to have equal strength solidarity, protection of natural life and specially going from competition which is really very male, kind of characteristic to a more cooperation.
What we consider a female.
Attitude to work.
Environment.
And last slide is a question which is very which I'm also trying to put through the Slovene government.
Why is you encouraging women for?
Of course, you growth to increase human potential, particularly enlarged U, as you have seen, we have nearly 50% of women PHD's and it's a shame that we do not use all there.
Intellectual and scientific potential to contribute to the scientific community.
For example, in European research area or in Slovenia or in any country and also we work for women themselves.

To be more knowledgeable, have more self confidence, be more ambitious to acquire adequate positions and salary, and then of course to teach younger and transfer their experience to the new generation to the younger generation which is important.
And they are learning very fast.
For example this.
Taken this summer and to see they are learning very fast from the adults.
